awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of Behavioral Innovation in Brood Parasitic Birds
awd_abstract_narration:
Songbirds are well-known for their complex vocalizations that, much like language in humans, are typically learned from their parents. But how do young that naturally lack contact with parents recognize members of their own species? Here, the researchers investigate the genomic, neurobiological and behavioral mechanisms of species recognition employed by avian brood parasites, birds whose eggs are laid into nests of strangers and whose chicks are raised by the foster species. By identifying the password--a species-specific vocalization that attracts and initiates the neural mechanisms by which young brood parasites identify individuals of their own species--the researchers will be able to understand how young that naturally lack contact with parents recognize members of their own species. This work will contribute broadly to scientific progress in the fields of learning and memory, behavioral plasticity and behavioral evolution. This research program involves training of students and young scientists, including a postdoctoral fellow and a diverse group of students, including many underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students in integrative behavioral, neurobiological, and genomics research techniques. The participants will deliver public seminars and exhibits at Sylvan Heights Bird Park in North Carolina and at several non-profit organizations in New York City.

The suite of behavioral innovations underlying social parasitism, including avian brood parasitism, must include mechanisms to recognize conspecifics without prior exposure during early development. This project will tap into the developmental knowledge already gathered from parental songbirds, including the zebra finch model system, and focus the ontogenetic study on a closely-related, but obligate parasitic finch, the pin-tailed whydah. The aim is to test the general hypothesis that differences in neural architecture or processing between parasitic and parental birds reflect evolutionary tinkering, whereby novel traits arise by modification of existing networks and structures. Through experimentally manipulated exposure of juvenile parasites to songs, the prediction will be tested that conspecific recognition relies on hearing a salient species-specific character, termed the password. Detailed quantitative patterns of transcriptional change following password exposure, and throughout developmental landmarks, will be collected to identify neurogenomic signatures associated with the timing and induction of conspecific recognition and to more broadly define the molecular basis of experience-dependent or developmentally driven neuroplasticity. Critical acoustic and behavioral components of these data will be collected during a newly developed field course in Puerto Rico. Acoustic and video data will be made freely available through DataOne, a public data repository, and genomic data will be deposited into the National Institutes of Health's NCBI short read archive.

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project explored the behavioral, developmental, and neurobiological basis of species recognition in two lineages of brood parasitic birds, including North American cowbirds and African whydahs.  Obligate brood parasitic birds lay their eggs in the nest of other species, forcing these hosts to care for the unrelated young in their brood. But how do brood parasites learn to recognize their own species if they cannot imprint on their foster parents?

The project has generated many conference presentations, 12+ published peer-reviewed papers and a book chapter, including a review of the current knowledge regarding the neural basis of acoustic species recognition in birds and data papers on the neurobiological substrate underlying species-specific auditory responses in the forebrains of parasitic birds. We used use behavioral, functional MRI, and neurogenomic approaches to accomplish project goals. 

The first major project explored whether brood parasitic birds use the same brain areas as non-parasitic (parental) birds to recognize vocal signatures of species identity: songs. For this aim, we compared published data on parental zebra finches, and analyzed gene-activational, fMRI, and behavioral data on closely related, but parasitic, pin-tailed whydahs. We found that indeed, parasites and non-parasites share the neural substrates used for auditory species recognition.

A second major project explored the neural basis of a password-based mechanism to identify other individuals from the same parasitic species. In this scenario, young parasites are attracted to others through a short, stereotyped call (the password), and once in the correct company, they learn other vocalizations and behavioral patterns regarding how to act like a parasite. For this study, we analyzed the neural gene-activation patterns of young and adult brown-headed cowbirds, and diagnosed the brain regions responsible for password-recognition and imitative vocal learning.

In support of the proposed aims we also generated three new whole genome assemblies, from two parasitic species and one host species. Using these new resources, we have examined the genomic changes associated with brood parasitism using comparative genomic approaches. Additionally, these genome sequences were contributed to a major international collaboration aimed at understanding genome evolution in birds more broadly.

One key Broader Impact of this project was the training a dedicated postdoctoral fellow in new techniques and analytical skills. The postdoc produced 7+ publications with the PIs as lead or co-author as an output of this grant. Additionally, under this award a major new exhibit, "Wings of the Tropics" was opened at Sylvan Heights Bird Park in Scotland Neck, North Carolina. This exhibit featured multiple brood parasitic species and signage describing the fascinating biology of brood parasitism.
